cards.title: Ashes / A roundup of England's 13-man Ashes squad
cards.rawTitle: A roundup of England's 13-man Ashes squad

item.title: England's Ashes Squad
item.trailText: We round up the England team to face Australia in the Ashes
item.standFirst: We round up the England team to face Australia in the Ashes

displayImages.caption:
Alastair Cook
Age 30
Caps 114
County Essex
Previous Ashes 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s captain and also their leading all-time Test run-scorer. In the 2010-11 Ashes in Australia he scored 766 runs at an average of 127, but also led the side in their whitewash defeat 18 months ago. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Alastair Cook
Age 30
Caps 114
County Essex
Previous Ashes 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14
England’s captain and also their leading all-time Test run-scorer. In the 2010-11 Ashes in Austrlia he scored 766 runs at an average of 127, but led the side to their whitewash defeat 18 months ago
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Alastair Cook
Age 30
Caps 114
County Essex
Previous Ashes 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s captain and also their leading all-time Test run-scorer. In the 2010-11 Ashes in Australia he scored 766 runs at an average of 127, but also led the side in their whitewash defeat 18 months ago.

displayImages.caption:
Moeen Ali
Age 28
Caps 11
County Worcestershire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Named one of Wisden’s Cricketers of the Year after an impressive 2014. The left-handed batsman made his debut against Sri Lanka at Lord’s last summer and scored a century in his second match. In the series that followed against India he took 19 wickets with his off-spin. Has not enjoyed quite the same success this summer and still has some way to go to be a leading Test match spinner. Photograph: Paul Ellis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Moeen Ali

displayImages.caption:
James Anderson
Age 32
Caps 102
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes 2006-7, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

England’s most experienced bowler and one of the best swingers of the ball in the world. Became England’s leading Test wicket-taker in the Caribbean earlier this year and then went past 400 wickets in the series against New Zealand. Considered by many Australians as England’s biggest sledger. Photograph: Stu Forster/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Gary Ballance
Age 25
Caps 13
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes 2013-14

Made his debut in the final Test of the 5-0 defeat in 2013-14 and has been a fixture since. An impressive record in his 13 Tests with a batting average of over 50, but his technique was brought into question by the New Zealand left-arm quick Trent Boult earlier this summer. Photograph: Ricardo Mazalan/AP
displayImages.altText:

displayImages.caption:
Ian Bell
Age 33
Caps 110
County Warwickshire
Previous Ashes 2005, 2006-07, 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Has struggled for runs since scoring a century in the first Test in the Caribbean. Was England’s best batsmen when they defeated the Australians at home two years ago and there are few finer cricketing sights than Bell in full flow. Photograph: Michael Steele/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:

displayImages.caption:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79
County Nottinghamshire
Previous Ashes 2009, 2010-11, 2013, 2013-14

Once viewed as an all-rounder but his batting skills have dipped alarmingly. Along with James Anderson, will lead England’s pace attack. Was England’s leading bowler in their 2009 Ashes win with 18 wickets. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Stuart Broad
Age 29
Caps 79

displayImages.caption:
Jos Buttler
Age 24
Caps 8
County Lancashire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Once seen as a one-day wicketkeeper-batsman specialist, but now destined to keep the gloves in the Test arena for years to come. A truly destructive batsman in the Adam Gilchrist mould, though still room to improve his keeping skills. Photograph: Philip Brown/Reuters
displayImages.altText:

displayImages.caption:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
County Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013

Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test, and played just one Test in the winning series at home months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position. Photograph: Gareth Copley/Getty Images
displayImages.altText:
Steven Finn
Age 26
Caps 23
Middlesex
Previous Ashes 2010-11, 2013
Went on England’s tour in 2013-14 but didn’t play in one Test despite the 5-0 defeat and had played just one game in the winning series in England months earlier. Made his England debut five years ago but has never held down a regular place. Will likely battle with Mark Wood for the third seamer’s position.

displayImages.caption:
Adam Lyth
Age 27
Caps 2
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Was selected on the tour of West Indies earlier this year after a stack of runs in county cricket, but kicked his heels in the Caribbean as England opted for Jonathan Trott at the top of the order. However, played in both Tests against New Zealand, scoring a century in the second one at Headingley, his home ground. Photograph: David Rogers/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Adil Rashid
Age 27
Caps 0
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes Debutant

Like his county colleague Adam Lyth, leg-spinner Rashid was selected for the tour of the Caribbean earlier this year but didn’t play in the Tests, a decision criticsed by many. He was overlooked, in favour of Moeen Ali, for the two Test series against New Zealand and also didn’t figure in England’s pre-Ashes training camp in Spain at the end of June. Can give the ball a rip but is also prone to bowling too many boundary balls. Photograph: Laurence Griffiths/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Joe Root
Age 24
Caps 27
County Yorkshire
Previous Ashes 2013, 2013-14

Appointed as vice-captain at the start of the summer and immediately went on to score 98 and 84 in the first Test against New Zealand. A gritty Yorkshireman who will be determined to improve on his one Test century against Australia. Photograph: Jewel Samad/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Ben Stokes
Age 24
Caps 11
County Durham
Previous Ashes 2013-14

The all-rounder was seen as one of the only successes of England’s tour to Australia 18 months ago. Made his debut in the second Test in Adelaide and in the third in Perth scored his maiden Test century. Has already lit up England’s summer by scoring the fastest ever Test century at Lord’s against New Zealand. Photograph: John Walton/PA

displayImages.caption:
Mark Wood
Age 25
Caps 2
County Durham
Previous Ashes Debutant

The right-arm paceman from Ashington made his debut against New Zealand at Lord’s in May and has nine wickets in his two matches. The one England bowler who appears to be able to bowl around 90mph with regularity. Photograph: Gareth Copley/Getty Images

cards.title: In pictures / Japan beat England in the semi-final of the Women's World Cup
cards.rawTitle: Japan beat England in the semi-final of the Women's World Cup

item.title: Women's World Cup: Japan beat England
item.trailText: The first senior England team to reach a international semi-final since 1990 takes on the defending champions. Here are the best photos of the match
item.standFirst:
They were the first senior England team to reach an international semi-final since Lineker and co at the 1990 World Cup. But, like their predecessors, they fell agonisingly short as an injury-time goal from Japan knocked them out of the tournament. Here are the best photos of the match
• Read the match report
• Japan beat England 1-0 – as it happened

cards.title: Football / Sweden jubilant following European Under-21 victory over Portugal
cards.rawTitle: Sweden jubilant following European Under-21 victory over Portugal

item.title: Sweden jubilant following European Under-21 victory over Portugal
item.trailText: Sweden's Under-21s striker John Guidetti and manager Håkan Ericson give their reactions after Sweden beat Portugal on penalties 4-3
item.standFirst: Sweden's Under-21s striker John Guidetti and manager Håkan Ericson give their reactions after Sweden beat Portugal on penalties 4-3 on Tuesday night in Prague. Guidetti says his side were mentally strong and ran more than every other team in the tournament. Ericson says Sweden were better prepared for the match than Portugal

cards.title: Cricket / The Wimbledon queue: through the eyes of a tournament veteran
cards.rawTitle: The Wimbledon queue: through the eyes of a tournament veteran

item.title: The Wimbledon queue: through the eyes of a tournament veteran
item.trailText: Hundreds of people camp out in order to secure an advantageous spot in the next morning's queue for tickets
item.standFirst: For the first 10 nights of Wimbledon, hundreds of people camp out in the adjacent Wimbledon Park in order to secure an advantageous spot in the next morning's queue for tickets. As many as 1,500 tickets are available for the show courts (Centre, One and Two) each day – and they are in high demand. We set our alarms to 'sunrise' to talk to Richard Hess, who's camping out for the 35th year

cards.rawTitle: Pink cricket balls for world's first day-night test

item.title: How it's made: Pink cricket balls for world's first day-night test
item.trailText: Pink cricket balls being produced at the Kookaburra factory in Melbourne
item.standFirst: Pink cricket balls being produced at the Kookaburra factory in Melbourne. The pink balls will be used in the world's first day-night Test match which will be played in Adelaide from 27 Nov-1 Dec between Australia and New Zealand. Cricket Australia announced the new format as an attempt to revive test match attendance and television ratings

cards.title: Football / Sampaoli: 'Now the dream begins' following win over Peru
cards.rawTitle: Sampaoli: 'Now the dream begins' following win over Peru

item.title: Chile's Jorge Sampaoli: 'Now the dream begins', following 2-1 win against Peru
item.trailText: Chile coach Jorge Sampoli and Peru's coach Ricardo Garceca comment on their teams' Copa América quarter-final match on Monday night
item.standFirst: Chile coach Jorge Sampoli and Peru's coach Ricardo Garceca comment on their teams' Copa América quarter-final match on Monday night. Chile beat Peru 2-1 and will now qualify for the semi-final of the Copa América tournament. Peru's Gareca says he is not satisfied with the loss, but adds that he is happy that his team did their best
